initial_comment.comment: Hi All, this file contains the protobuf messages and the relative flow with the security checks to put in place. This a joint effort with <@U1BC5A0F9> and <@U26T99AQ4>.

Request from <@U0XPR4NP4> to accommodate simpler types of transactions that contain either reconfiguration requests, or simply hashes of transactions.
Reconfiguration may concern either the fabric-network (endorsers) or the ordering service.
<@U1QUW6W82|michele> has joined the channel

<@U1BC5A0F9>, on page 11, it shows that the proposal form the SDK has an entry for chaincode simulation but if this comes form the SDK it’s going to be hard to have the SDK perform the simulation. Wouldn’t relying on the simulation information back from the endorsers be enough? the client has always the option of not submitting the transaction if things are different than expected...
So, this is actually an optional field

that is the client would send to the peer (the first peer he contacts) a proposal that does not contain simulation result. Then that peer will compute simulation result based on his state info and return a response to the client, that the latter will use in the proposals to the rest of endorsers.
understood
we need to be careful that the other proposals may have a hash different from the first one I guess
<@U1BC5A0F9> <@U0ULK2JPP> Can we talk and nail down some changes to the transaction format?
If you could send us the proto (non-pdf) <@U0ULK2JPP> and I could do the proposed changes and send back so that we can discuss

Great, thanks!

so it is for everyone to have a say there?
Sounds good
<@U0ZR63HLK> can you paste here a link to the submitted protos so that we can take a look (apologies I’m not very familiar with gerrit :slightly_smiling_face: )
sure, actually what I can also do is to submit a mail to the mailing list
gotta go and subscribe to that too then :slightly_smiling_face:
hehhe :slightly_smiling_face:
there’s many lists :smile: would that be the hyperledger-fabric one?
Here is the change-set: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1561/>
thanks!
on a side note: has anyone investigated the overhead of splitting serialization and deserialization in multiple substructures as opposed to a single bigger structure?

for example proposal has a header and a payload that are serialized separately, is there significant performance penalty (or advantage) to doing this as opposed to serializing one data structure that contains both?
It’s much cleaner than the previous one :slightly_smiling_face:
you did not remove the fabric_next.proto etc in the parent dir though
<@U0KQ9QKH6|pmullaney> has joined the channel

<@U1QUW6W82> I'm not sure if you're aware (it was news to me not so long ago), but protobuf structures do not serialize deterministically, so a signature cannot be over an unmarshaled struct, as two users might serializes it to different bytes and correspondingly verify or not verify the signature.  I think that is why there is so much embedding of marshaled objects, or, maybe you're spotting something else?  I know <@U0XR6J961> was pushing for us to switch to ASN1 for things which we sign over, though its encoding is noticeably slower than protobuf.
<@U1QUW6W82>, what I submitted is not intended to be merged as it is. The goal is to collect feedback and then find the right way to merge it

<@U0Y14MWA2>, <@U0ZR63HLK>, <@U0XPR4NP4>, <@U0XR6J961>: do you think it would make sense that we support transactions whose execution takes place "after the total ordering takes place"? That is accommodate transactions where the VSCC is the actual execution of the invocation info, as long as they are deterministic?
It may make sense for system updates, etc.
<@U1BC5A0F9> is this code to be deployed at runtime or precompiled (like vscc)?
hm if system chaincode, it would be part of the genesis block i guess
(these are the ones i would consider this being useful for)
for the user chaincodes/trabsactions, we would not want to support this (for non-determinism dangers)
If this cannot be deployed by a user/chaincode/tx I am fine
<@U1BC5A0F9> re our discussion - how would you implement bitcoin in HL i would implement it precisely like that
Not as chaincode
Correct. And assuming that we do not have a set of "priviledged" endorsers to "endorse" system chaincode state changes, maybe such transaction type would make things easier.

<@U1BC5A0F9> _hm if system chaincode, it would be part of the genesis block i guess_ system chaincodes are treated as part of the fabric code and not deployed via transaction (ie, will not be in a block, even the genesis block)… I dont think it matters for your argument in any case. Just wanted to make sure to set the record straight (no pun intended :slightly_smiling_face: )
<@U0ULK2JPP>, right; but arent the transactions invoking these also subjected to some ESCC/VSCC?
they should be, yes, but not currently as the system chaincode definition has not been extended to specify ESCC/VSCC,
we have to make special case for eSCC/VSCC themselves
or make sure they cannot be invoked like other chaincodes can
need to get ready for office… online with 1.5 hrs
ok!

I have been reviewing the current code base in feature/convergence/sdk/node in light of the protobufmessagesandflow.pdf doc. Questions - 1) Where is the code in the node sdk in reference to the protobufmessagesandflow.pdf doc? It appears not to have implemented this. 2) There appears to be no concept of dynamic endorsers (where the endorsers are defined by the client or context of the information. Is this planned on being supported? 3) There is no concept of channels yet. Any idea when it will be reflected? 4) How is external peer information expected to be configured / maintained?
<@U1FDTCEUR> suggest you take this to <#C25AQBS4B|fabric-sdk-dev> or <#C29512UHF|fabric-sdk-node-dev>

<@U1FDTCEUR> : here's a tentative set of answers

1) Where is the code in the node sdk in reference to the protobufmessagesandflow.pdf doc? It appears not to have implemented this. 

There's no code so far, only the definitions of the various messages here <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1561/1>

2) There appears to be no concept of dynamic endorsers (where the endorsers are defined by the client or context of the information. Is this planned on being supported? 

There is indeed no notion of an endorser set (yet) and the requirements aren't fully clear yet (at least to us). Here's some ideas: this may either be handled by the existing chainID field in the ProposalHeader message (assuming a static set of endorsers has been assigned to a particular chainID); or it may be handled via channels by a (yet-to-be-defined) channelID field; or by an extension of the ProposalHeader where endorsers are somehow listed.

3) There is no concept of channels yet. Any idea when it will be reflected? 

See above

4) How is external peer information expected to be configured / maintained?

You've lost me here

<@U26T99AQ4> <@U0KM61BCP> - Thanks for the responses. Regarding question 2 (dynamic endorsers). Our Use Case uses a single user chaincode to process transactions for mulitple trading pairs. By trading pair I mean the party and counter party to a particular transaction. We will need to use the channels to isolate these into separate ledgers. May I suggest that the easiest way to provide a dynamic endorsement set is to include the endorser list as an input attribute to the SDK. This would be fine for our use case. The only potential downside would be a malicious client sending in a bad endorser set. As we are doing bi-lateral contract processing this would have no impact. Another way that we could make it work is associating the endorser set with a channel id.

<@U26T99AQ4> Regarding question 4 about external peer configuration. The question is for any given peer, how does it know the end points for a particular endorser? For example - Client A wants an endorsement from Client B and C. How does Client A know the endpoints for B and C to make the endorsement request? Is it expected to be obtained from Member Services? Manual Configuration? Public Blockchain information?

<@U1FDTCEUR> thx for the clarification. On point 2: if I understood correctly, you are saying that at the application level, this will be handled by accepting an additional input identifying a set of endorsers. Internally, this will be mapped into _something_ that the fabric understands, potentially a channel ID or a chain ID.

On point 4: gotcha and yes, personally I know no way in which this is accomplished today. I had a quick look and I tentatively convinced myself that the message definitions aren't directly impacted by this, though. Provided that there is a way of listing endorsers (and we're back to your previous observation), the translation mechanism between this list and actual service endpoints is orthogonal imho - would you agree?
<@U26T99AQ4> On point 2 - the endorser set would need to be associated with a channel ID, not a chain ID. The same chain ID would be used for ALL trading pairs (channel IDs).

<@U26T99AQ4>  On point 4 - Not sure what definition for orthogonal you are using here, so not sure if I agree or dont agree. The whole point of the question was how does the SDK implementation know the endpoint to send an endorsement to? In our situation this would be compounded by the need to either translate the endorsement set from either a method attribute input list of endorser ids, or by associating the endorser list to a channel id. So at some level the SDK needs to be able to obtain a grpc connection to an endpoint that is identified by the endorser id. This endorser is probably a Member. I guess the key is that somehow the SDK needs to be able to either manage this or accept the configuration as input.

on point 4: what I was trying to say was that I think your observations don't directly impact the message definition. As long as the channel ID is part of the fields of the relevant messages, we're fine from a message perspective. However I agree that the SDK interfaces need to be changed to include the notion of endorser set or channel ID.

<@U1FDTCEUR> : For point 4, i think <@U0S5KF44D> mentioned that the client has the luxury of querying the membership service to indeed find out "contact" info on the endorsers that relate to a specific chaincode.  But as <@U26T99AQ4> says, after the client learns this information, the message structure is not impacted :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0S5KF44D|keithsmith> has joined the channel

I have a question in slide Endorser message flow in the Fabric proto slide deck. I am not sure if I understand the difference between three visibility modes. 1)Identity function 2) cryptographic hash function 3) function returning a zero-length byte array
we have a `visibility field` in the ```ChaincodeproposalHeaderExtension```. Is there a more detailed description of each of these three modes?

<@U1BC5A0F9> This isn’t ringing any bells.  A single membership services (aka “cop server”) is per-participant, but there will be chaincode which manages all of the participants trusted CA roots.  I’m not sure if that is what you were thinking of

Hm, ok i remember we had a discussion over how a client who wishes to invoke chaincode with identifier, say chaincodeID, can find out which endorsers to contact. And then there was a question of whether this client should do a query to a peer /endorser it trusts to give it this information (given a system chaincode state), and then locally ask the client-side of membership service (that can extend the request to the server) to list the network information of that endorser.

<@U24M29R4G> the visibility field controls to which extent the 'ChaincodeProposalInputs' (inside the original Proposal) is part of the final 'Transaction' message AND how is it included in the proposalHash field of the ProposalResponsePayload message. Imagine visibility accepts three values for the three functions you described: 
1) if it's set to "identity function", the bytes of ChaincodeProposalInputs are stored in ChaincodeProposalPayload (in the ChaincodeActionsPayload field) and they are fully hashed into proposalHash (alongside the ProposalHeader);
2) if it's set to "hash function", H(ChaincodeProposalInputs) is stored in ChaincodeProposalPayload (in the ChaincodeActionsPayload field) and it is hashed into proposalHash (alongside the ProposalHeader);
3) if it's set to "empty byte array", then ChaincodeProposalPayload is empty and proposalHash only hashes the ProposalHeader;
